nexttext:
where $\eta$ denotes conformal time and $u_i$ is the (spatial) velocity of the source. The Einstein convention is used with $i$ running over the spatial indices $1,2,3$. The vector $n^{\mu}$ is the propagation direction unit $4$-vector, {\em i.e.} $n^{\mu} \propto k^{\mu}+\frac{k^{\nu}u_{\nu}}{c^2}u^{\mu}$. It is sufficient to use the background version of $n^{\mu}$ and in that case $n^{i}$ is the unit vector pointing in the direction from the source to the observer. 
\newline\indent
In the expression for the Doppler convergence given above, a term due to the peculiar motion of the observer has been omitted. This is justified by noting that the observer velocity can be estimated by measuring the CMB dipole and hence has no consequences when interpreting real observations. Note also that in equation (\ref{eq:Doppler}), the scale factor etc. are evaluated at the spacetime position corresponding to the {\em observed} redshift $z_{\text{obs}}$, not a background redshift computed with the background metric. 
\newline\indent
When mock redshift-distance data points have been obtained as described above, they are fitted to the expression for the luminosity distance in an FLRW universe,

where $\eta$ denotes conformal time and $u_i$ is the (spatial) velocity of the source. The Einstein convention is used with $i$ running over the spatial indices $1,2,3$. The vector $n^{\mu}$ is the propagation direction unit $4$-vector, {\em i.e.} $n^{\mu} \propto k^{\mu}+\frac{k^{\nu}u_{\nu}}{c^2}u^{\mu}$.
